This is an octal listing of the assembled code of

column3: PTC ADAPT Self-Test Program (for modified LVDC), as
transcribed directly from the assembly listing.

# Copyright:: # This is a transcription of the octal listing found at the end of the
# assembly listing for LVDC program PTC ADAPT Self-Test Program.  In terms
# of the zipfile of scanned page images linked above, the octal listing
# starts at p. 221. Lines beginning with '#' in column 1 have been added
# afterward, and should be treated as comments. Empty lines should also be
# The active lines are tab-delimited.  I.e., they consist of fields with
# tab characters separating the fields.  The active lines are of two types.

Lines with 4 fields:  Beginning of the listing for a specific memory sector.

column4: Description of proofing passes completed. A notation

column5: like V(n) (where n is a decimal number) means that a
visual proofing pass was completed and n errors were
found during it.  A(n) means an audio proofing pass
was completed with n errors found.  A(n,m) means the
same, except that it also indicates that m undetected
errors were found afterward by unsystematic means.
Only one sector pass used the audio method, and since
more errors were found afterward than were detected by
the pass, only visual passes were performed thereafter.
By my count 186 errors were corrected during the 1st
proofing pass, and 2 during the second. I would infer
that about 99% of the remaining errors are detected on
each visual-proofing pass, therefore the likely number
of errors remaining is about .02 ... i.e., that no
errors remain.  However, that argument is merely
statistical, and hardly authoritative.

Lines with 9:  Contain the assembled octal data.  The format *differs* from the
octal-table format in the AS206-RAM assembly listing.

column4: Octal starting address of the line within the sector

column5: 3 digits are some sort of semantic data produced by the
assembler.  Considered in binary, I think the scheme is
something like this:  000 000 0ba, where:

column6: a = 1 if syllable 0 is used, 0 if not used.
b = 1 if syllable 1 is used, 0 if not used.

column5: Regarding the leftmost 10 digits, this value is identical
to the 26-bit data constant or packed dual 13-bit instructions
assembled at the two syllables of the corresponding addresses.
